newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN SUGAR - BANGLADESH BUYS 25,000T WHITE SUGAR.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN SUGAR - BANGLADESH BUYS 25,000T WHITE SUGAR.

text.p: Bangladesh bought 25,000 tonnes of white sugar at US$339.70 per tonne on Tuesday for September shipment, Hong Kong trade sources said on Wednesday.
"I think that was the best price on offer," said one sugar trader.
Bidding for Bangladesh state-owned Sugar and Food Industries Corp's 25,000-tonne sugar tender took place on July 20th.
Otherwise, physical markets in Asia were quiet, with little activity seen as destinations faded away.
"I havn't seen Thais traded in a week," said another source. The market was attempting to assess how badly hit Thailand's sugar crop would be and trying to plan accordingly.
Estimates ranged from a 15-to-20 percent drop, Hong Kong sources said.
Dry weather was creating havoc in Thailand on top of the country's worst economic slump.
The sugar market had been largely dominated by futures and speculator buying while Asia's physical markets lay low, traders said.
New York's Coffee Sugar and Cocao Exchanges' world sugar futures climbed on fund buying with the benchmark October contract ending on Tuesday 0.33 cents higher at 11.59 cents a lb.

Thai raw sugar premiums were quoted slightly lower from Friday, with July/September deliveries quoted at 0.85/0.95 cent a pound over New York's Coffee Sugar and Cocoa Exchange futures on an FOB basis, sources said.
On Friday, Thai raw sugar premiums for July/September deliveries were quoted at around 90/100 points.
In China, white sugar prices ex-factory in the southern producing province of Guangdong had edged back up to 4,000 yuan per tonne this week, sources said.

Traders said they were bullish over next year's sugar buying in Asia, with a reduced Thai sugar crop, and Indonesia expected to match this year's sugar buying at between 700,000 and one million tonnes.
China remained a question mark, with some traders convinced China would enter the market in 1998 and other sceptical.
China's sugar output totalled 4.65 million tonnes in the first half of this year, up 12.6 percent compared with the year-ago period, the State Statistical Bureau said on Tuesday.
